module.p: Anthroponymic name-descriptions are name-descriptions which are also anthroponyms – specified common noun phrases which name individual persons (and other personified entities like toys, boats, pets ) – An Caiptean The Captain, Bean Alasdair Alexander’s Wife.
Anthroponymic name-descriptions contrast with anthroponymic proper nouns like Mairead Margaret or Seumas James.

section.p:
Pre-specified –
topoanthroponyms (the common noun is ethnonymic) – am Moireach the Duke of Atholl, am Muileach Hector MacLachlain, the Man from Mull, an Bàideanach the Badenoch man (Calder 1923: 105)
military ranks – an Caiptean the Captain, an Còirneal the Colonel
derived from ethnonymic common nouns – am Frisealach Fraser, an Caimbeulach dubh black Campbell (all from Calder 1923: 105)

Post-specified –
topoanthroponyms – Fear Canaidh John Lorne Campbell of Canna, Fear Chìosmuil MacNeil of Barra, Morair Ghalaibh the Earl of Caithness, Siosalach Shrathghlais Chisholm of Chisholm, Triath Dhubhairt MacLean of Duart
gamonyms (anthropoanthroponyms) – Bean Alasdair Alexander’s wife, banntrach Uilleim William’s widow
patronyms (anthropoanthroponyms) – Mac Cailein Mòr the Duke of Argyll, Mac Chailein Mhic Dhonnachaidh the Earl of Breadalbane, Mac Dhòmhnaill Dhuibh Cameron of Lochiel, Mac Gille Chaluim MacLeod of Raasay, Mac Iain MacDonald of Glencoe, Mac Mhic Ailein MacDonald of Clanranald, Mac Mhic Alasdair MacDonald of Glengarry, MacShimidh Lord Lovat (Fraser),

The head (ie. initial) noun in a (post-specified) anthroponymic name-description which is itself the (genitive) (post-)specifier of another noun is generally not lenited –
taigh Fear Chìosmuil MacNeil of Barra’s house, cf. taigh Fhear Chìosmuil
cù Bean Alastair Alexander’s Wife’s dog, cf. cù Bhean Alastair
peann Ceannard a’ Bhùird the Chairman of the Board’s pen, cf. peann Cheannard a’ Bhùird
